positive.review: I've been playing this game since very early access. I have watched how its grown and improved over time and how they listened to what they're community was saying and requesting. I remember sending a request report asking for co-op, a few months later they made it work. I got my friends to start playing with me and our only real complaint was the time it took to get from one end of the map to the other. They listened to the community and added teleporters and a vehicle. The community wanted a bit more endgame, they added the portal generator and the free DLC moons that you can go too after beating your planet. They've just released a 2nd paid DLC for even more planets to explore and they made the non-greedy decision to make it so only host has to have DLC. This game and community is loved and cared for by the developers and I'm beyond proud to recommend this game to anyone and everyone.

Absolutely gorgeous game. 

The Planet Crafter is full of eye candy, satisfying features and mechanics, and the sound design and soundtrack are just [i]chef's kiss[/i]. I fell in love with this game the moment I started playing it. It's very comfy and rewarding, and the whole process of terraforming planets is immensely satisfying - as well as exploring them, and uncovering all the hidden lore on them. There's so many cool and beautiful things to see, and to see the landscapes surrounding you change from barren to beautiful and full of lush nature as you shape and terraform them, is absolutely terrific. Plus, building your base and managing it is very satisfying as well. I especially like how you're able to build and decorate your bases with great care, and how you can make them quite cozy and visually appealing. IMO the game is really enjoyable in single player because it'll feel very serene and easy-going, but playing it with friends definitely adds even more to the enjoyment.

As for the less than great stuff: sometimes you'll stumble upon a bug or two, or venture out into a part of a map where you can clearly see there has been an oversight in modeling the environment, or reach places where you walk or fall through the terrain. But this doesn't detract from the enjoyment of the game at all. The devs even included a way for you to unstuck your character and your vehicle! So these somewhat quirky bugs can be totally forgiven. Plus, driving under the base of a friend of mine in the rover and abusing the unstuck key to make it clip into the base made us lose our shit.

Speaking of the rover, this is probably the one thing I wish felt a little more polished. Driving the rover can be pretty janky. I've had situations where I'd get stuck in spots which were hard to get out of with it. But again, not something which actually detracted from my enjoyment, just a minor irritation which was quickly forgotten. And besides, the devs thought of situations where the rover is unable to get out of a spot as well, since you can simply recall the rover to your vehicle station.

One last mini complaint, which I recognize is purely because I struggle with sensory disorders (namely, autism and misophonia): some of the menu/interaction sounds in this game can be a little sharp and/or grating. My solution to this is simply setting the menu sounds to 50% volume. Easy fix. This likely won't be a problem for a large majority of the players, but since these sounds are something that didn't sit well with my aforementioned conditions, I feel like it's going to help out at least someone when pointing them out.

All in all, I love this game. Highly recommended for fans of comfy games, as well as space/sci-fi themed games. You're going to sink many hours into this and not regret it. Grab the DLCs while you're at it. At this time of writing, I haven't been able to buy the Toxicity DLC yet, but all the other DLCs have been a great addition, and the reviews of the Toxicity DLC so far have been absolutely glowing, so I'm excited to get it in a few days. Part of me feels like the Humble DLC could've been a little bigger and better though, but playing it has been really enjoyable regardless. Miju Games has definitely got something great going on with this game. 10/10

Planet Crafter is an excellent adaptation of the survival-craft genre, incorporating environmental transformation by way of terraforming into the gameplay experience. Note: highly habit-forming. Note 2: building your survival hut in the center of a valley at altitude zero is probably not a good idea prior to atmospheric seeding. Note 3: jetpack. Note 4: hold your eggplants and squash under the local Tier 3 drill's beam for a rapid cooking process. Never get tired of raw veggies again!

The optimisation machine is janky and doesn't reach every machine nearby since the ground isn't flat, and some building cannot be build on concrete which would have fixed this complaint. The hunger and thirst quickly become annoying since you easily get the ressource needed to full them and only need to remember to use them. The place where the game put you at the start became full of water so we've had to move the entire base at that point which sucked. And the craft 1k thing doesn't work for the non host of the world.

The game can be cool at the start, but become a lots of idling toward the end so keep that in mind while purchasing.

I was seriously and positively surprised by Planet Crafter. It turned out to be so much more than I expected. The game is an incredibly fun and varied co-op experience where multiple players can jump in and each take on their own tasks. Whether you're gathering resources, building the base, exploring new areas, or managing production, there’s always something meaningful to do and it all comes together in a really satisfying way.

What impressed me most is how well the game blends adventure, base-building, and progression. Watching the planet slowly transform because of your teamwork feels amazing, and the co-op aspect makes every session engaging and unique.

The only downside is that the person who owns the world needs to be online for everyone else to play together on that world. It’s not a big issue, but it can be inconvenient sometimes.

Overall, I genuinely recommend this game to anyone looking for a great co-op title with exploration, creativity, and long-term development. Planet Crafter delivers far more than you’d expect  in the best possible way.

So- to be clear, I do actually enjoy Planet Crafter and I do really want to recommend it, it's exactly the kind of game I love. However, there are a few things that prevent me from recommending it. The TL;DR is that there are a few clunky and at times frustrating things that need to be adjusted before I can recommend it.

Firstly, this is a game about building things to terraform the planet. However, building a base is rather difficult. The first thing you'll run into is the fact that foundations don't snap or align to buildings- at least, not automatically. However, this is honestly more of a minor gripe, this doesn't cause that much of an issue other than minor frustration with some foundation placement- but perfectionists beware, the foundations and buildings are hard to align and it's hard to get a good camera angle to make sure they are aligned.
But the big issue is the act of building itself. One speed bump (literally) is how the small inventory and ability to find iron in early game is rather limiting for building a base. The iron issue does eventually get resolved, however, building a large structure can still be rather limited by even the late-game inventory size- you'll be running around a LOT (this isn't super bad, but it can make building more of a chore than fun). Secondly, I actually find it unironically interesting that the devs decided to make it where many things can just be built in the air at a preset distance from the player- rather than, for example, having to build them off of other buildings or the ground (though you can still do both here). I've always wondered how such a building mechanic might work, and honestly, it does work... with a lot of frustration at times. The problem being that buildings like to snap from one particular preset wall- in particular, the indoor stairs are two levels tall and want to snap from the bottom. This can make it difficult to build down. I spent a LOT of time trying to build a staircase down from my base- admittedly, I shouldn't have built it so high up, but it was also unreasonably frustrating to place indoor stairs down from it (which I had to do because indoor stairs are unlocked around mid game- had to use outdoor stairs before that).

Another issue is movement. The first issue is that gravity is always unreasonably strong and you plummet to the ground the second you step off a platform (would be neat if the gravity changed over time, btw!). Hunger and health are the same resource bar (drains over time)- which is an odd choice but I respect the simplicity- but it's really easy to die by falling. There is something to help though- a jetpack that you can make pretty early on. It hovers a certain exact distance from the ground- though you can make it fly higher or lower extremely briefly (it's based on where you're looking, which is a little odd, and kind of interesting actually, but sometimes annoying). The problem is the plummeting issue. You can save yourself from falling with the jetpack, but it's difficult to tell if the jetpack is working after an accidental fall because you still plummet until you're at the preset distance above the ground where you would float. By the time you can tell it's not working, you've already taken damage or died. If you were already jetpacking before you went off a ledge, you will still drop rather rapidly down to whatever the appropriate hovering distance above the ground is, which means it's very easy to lose your altitude. The reason this is a major problem is because the jetpack is very useful but very frustrating to use for building. If you move, your altitude will change based on the terrain and that can totally throw you off of where you were trying to build. It also changes your height based on where you're looking while jetpacking which can really jimmy things up for building. You can be hovering but not moving and you will bob around a bit- I assume this is because I'm changing the angle of the camera, which changes the altitude of hovering. On that note, I can respect the simplicity of the jetpack- but man, it makes for clunky building. 

Returning to building, the buildings that you will need to attach to your base can vary in shape widely (as in, come in non-standard sizes) and can be difficult to attach to your base. This may be an intentional design- to which I say, neat puzzle, but it can be hard to see where or how a building attaches to a building. There are a lot of buildings that can be difficult to tessellate with a base. But this is mostly a minor gripe.

For being a crafting game, it's a bit clunky to craft en masse. The problem I have is that multi-crafting is an optional setting and not the default. You have to hold CTRL to craft multiple items or build multiple buildings- if you don't, it makes one and kicks you out of the menu or takes away the building hologram. This makes base building clunky- having to hold CTRL while you try to find the right snaps for your buildings (remember the jetpack problem!). Multi-craft and multi-build should really be the default, and this game could learn a lot from the way Satisfactory handles buildings.

Another problem I do have with Planet Crafter is a lack of organization. In the late game, it can be difficult to sift through the long list of buildings or supply/demand request lists and they really need more categories. In addition, this game desperately needs an in-game wiki that can at least tell you at which crafting station or building you can build a certain item, if not also the recipe for that item. You will unlock something out of the blue and you'll want to make it, but in order to do that, you'll have to run around and go through every crafting station you own to see where it's built. You may not even have the crafting station yet or didn't know something even was a crafting station and you'll find yourself confused for a long while until you figure it out or google it. I didn't have as much of an issue with this problem though because I played with someone who has played the game before and he could tell me where to look- but I can imagine that I or an inexperienced player might get frustrated with that. If you're okay with using the wiki (which is unfortunately a Fandom wiki, be sure to use an adblocker), this isn't an issue.

Another gripe I have is also that the numbers are laughably low and it kind of breaks the immersion.
Your temperature starts at 0 K which simply isn't possible. Even in my late game playthrough now (past the "complete terraformation" stage), I'm at 2,000 mK (yes, it still reads it as mK) which means it's at a whopping 2 K. There's no way anything living would survive at that temperature even if it were possible for the temperature to be that low. You also achieve a liquid water stage long before that. Just as a reminder, 0 degrees C / 32 degrees F (freezing point of water at standard pressure) is about 273 K.
You also start at 0 ppq oxygen, which is maybe plausible, but you can get to a "breathable atmosphere" stage at very low ppm of oxygen. I'm long past that, and I'm at about 5,000ppm oxygen (yes, it does read ppm instead of ppt) which is 0.5% oxygen. You need a bare minimum of 19.5% oxygen to breathe.
And you start at 0 nPa pressure, which is impossible. Even if it were possible, that means the planet wouldn't have enough gravity to hold on to any gasses, which makes creating oxygen rather moot- it would just go off into space. In my current game, I'm at 1,600 Pa, which is ridiculously low. Earth's standard pressure is about 100,000 Pa.
If we were to align these numbers more to reality, it would feel more believable, immersive, and even educational while still being entertaining. And yes, I know there's a system terraformation index, but the numbers can be changed to make that work properly. 

There's fun to be had here- but it needs more polish. Things were created in a simple manner but lazily implemented, which I think is my biggest issue with the game.

In my opinion, The Planet Crafter becomes repetitive fairly quickly. While the core idea of terraforming a barren world is exciting, the gameplay loop often settles into the same routine: gather resources, place machines, watch the numbers climb, and move on. After some time, this cycle starts to feel more like waiting than meaningful progression.

The building system also leaves a lot to be desired. Construction doesn’t feel smooth, and the game doesn’t offer much creative freedom when designing bases. Interiors often look awkward and disconnected. Decorative objects are hard to place nicely, frequently ending up misaligned, something that can be especially irritating for players who care about symmetry or aesthetics. Inside bases, the appearance of multiple structural pillars makes rooms look cluttered or visually unpleasant, breaking the sense of immersion instead of enhancing it.

Co-op gameplay has its own immersion-breaking issue: when a friend dies, there’s no option to revive them. They simply disappear in front of you, which removes emotional impact and eliminates interesting gameplay opportunities, like emergency rescues or support-based mechanics.

Inventory management also becomes frustrating. Items don’t stack, so your inventory fills up extremely quickly when gathering materials. Instead of creating a meaningful limitation, this system often just interrupts the flow of exploration. A more interesting alternative could be a weight-based system, forcing players to decide whether to gather more resources at the risk of running out of oxygen because they move slower or take longer to return.

On top of that, although exploration is pleasant at first, many areas follow a similar pattern: visit a wreck, loot what you can, bring it home, and repeat. Even as new biomes emerge during terraformation, the core experience doesn’t evolve as much as it could.

Despite all these shortcomings, the game genuinely has a lot of potential. Watching the world gradually transform can be incredibly satisfying, and the slow, atmospheric pace can be quite relaxing. The developers are active, and the community often praises their commitment to improving the game. However, for me, the repetitive nature of the progression and the limitations in building and inventory eventually wore me down. I ended up getting tired before reaching the phase where the planet becomes fully alive.

Overall, The Planet Crafter is enjoyable for players who like slow-paced survival and incremental progress. But if you’re looking for deep building mechanics, varied exploration, or more dynamic co-op systems, you might find it getting repetitive sooner than expected.

Inventory management is absolutely terrible. Storage feels limited, crafting menus are messy, poorly organized, and navigation feels like a chore. Items don’t stack, so you will end up spamming a bunch of boxes to store the immense amount of resources you’ll gather.

All of these problems together and probably some more I haven’t experienced because I couldn’t bear to play more of it, make the game feel far less polished than it should be. Yeah, you terraform. Big deal. The whole thing basically boils down to “gather → build → wait for a number to go up → repeat.” According to user reviews, the automation is weak, inventory sucks, and there’s no real reward for grinding.

So- to be clear, I do actually enjoy Planet Crafter and I do really want to recommend it, it's exactly the kind of game I love. However, there are a few things that prevent me from recommending it. The TL;DR is that there are a few clunky and at times frustrating things that need to be adjusted before I can recommend it.

Firstly, this is a game about building things to terraform the planet. However, building a base is rather difficult. The first thing you'll run into is the fact that foundations don't snap or align to buildings- at least, not automatically. However, this is honestly more of a minor gripe, this doesn't cause that much of an issue other than minor frustration with some foundation placement- but perfectionists beware, the foundations and buildings are hard to align and it's hard to get a good camera angle to make sure they are aligned.
But the big issue is the act of building itself. One speed bump (literally) is how the small inventory and ability to find iron in early game is rather limiting for building a base. The iron issue does eventually get resolved, however, building a large structure can still be rather limited by even the late-game inventory size- you'll be running around a LOT (this isn't super bad, but it can make building more of a chore than fun). Secondly, I actually find it unironically interesting that the devs decided to make it where many things can just be built in the air at a preset distance from the player- rather than, for example, having to build them off of other buildings or the ground (though you can still do both here). I've always wondered how such a building mechanic might work, and honestly, it does work... with a lot of frustration at times. The problem being that buildings like to snap from one particular preset wall- in particular, the indoor stairs are two levels tall and want to snap from the bottom. This can make it difficult to build down. I spent a LOT of time trying to build a staircase down from my base- admittedly, I shouldn't have built it so high up, but it was also unreasonably frustrating to place indoor stairs down from it (which I had to do because indoor stairs are unlocked around mid game- had to use outdoor stairs before that).

Another issue is movement. The first issue is that gravity is always unreasonably strong and you plummet to the ground the second you step off a platform (would be neat if the gravity changed over time, btw!). Hunger and health are the same resource bar (drains over time)- which is an odd choice but I respect the simplicity- but it's really easy to die by falling. There is something to help though- a jetpack that you can make pretty early on. It hovers a certain exact distance from the ground- though you can make it fly higher or lower extremely briefly (it's based on where you're looking, which is a little odd, and kind of interesting actually, but sometimes annoying). The problem is the plummeting issue. You can save yourself from falling with the jetpack, but it's difficult to tell if the jetpack is working after an accidental fall because you still plummet until you're at the preset distance above the ground where you would float. By the time you can tell it's not working, you've already taken damage or died. If you were already jetpacking before you went off a ledge, you will still drop rather rapidly down to whatever the appropriate hovering distance above the ground is, which means it's very easy to lose your altitude. The reason this is a major problem is because the jetpack is very useful but very frustrating to use for building. If you move, your altitude will change based on the terrain and that can totally throw you off of where you were trying to build. It also changes your height based on where you're looking while jetpacking which can really jimmy things up for building. You can be hovering but not moving and you will bob around a bit- I assume this is because I'm changing the angle of the camera, which changes the altitude of hovering. On that note, I can respect the simplicity of the jetpack- but man, it makes for clunky building. 

Returning to building, the buildings that you will need to attach to your base can vary in shape widely (as in, come in non-standard sizes) and can be difficult to attach to your base. This may be an intentional design- to which I say, neat puzzle, but it can be hard to see where or how a building attaches to a building. There are a lot of buildings that can be difficult to tessellate with a base. But this is mostly a minor gripe.

For being a crafting game, it's a bit clunky to craft en masse. The problem I have is that multi-crafting is an optional setting and not the default. You have to hold CTRL to craft multiple items or build multiple buildings- if you don't, it makes one and kicks you out of the menu or takes away the building hologram. This makes base building clunky- having to hold CTRL while you try to find the right snaps for your buildings (remember the jetpack problem!). Multi-craft and multi-build should really be the default, and this game could learn a lot from the way Satisfactory handles buildings.

Another problem I do have with Planet Crafter is a lack of organization. In the late game, it can be difficult to sift through the long list of buildings or supply/demand request lists and they really need more categories. In addition, this game desperately needs an in-game wiki that can at least tell you at which crafting station or building you can build a certain item, if not also the recipe for that item. You will unlock something out of the blue and you'll want to make it, but in order to do that, you'll have to run around and go through every crafting station you own to see where it's built. You may not even have the crafting station yet or didn't know something even was a crafting station and you'll find yourself confused for a long while until you figure it out or google it. I didn't have as much of an issue with this problem though because I played with someone who has played the game before and he could tell me where to look- but I can imagine that I or an inexperienced player might get frustrated with that. If you're okay with using the wiki (which is unfortunately a Fandom wiki, be sure to use an adblocker), this isn't an issue.

Another gripe I have is also that the numbers are laughably low and it kind of breaks the immersion.
Your temperature starts at 0 K which simply isn't possible. Even in my late game playthrough now (past the "complete terraformation" stage), I'm at 2,000 mK (yes, it still reads it as mK) which means it's at a whopping 2 K. There's no way anything living would survive at that temperature even if it were possible for the temperature to be that low. You also achieve a liquid water stage long before that. Just as a reminder, 0 degrees C / 32 degrees F (freezing point of water at standard pressure) is about 273 K.
You also start at 0 ppq oxygen, which is maybe plausible, but you can get to a "breathable atmosphere" stage at very low ppm of oxygen. I'm long past that, and I'm at about 5,000ppm oxygen (yes, it does read ppm instead of ppt) which is 0.5% oxygen. You need a bare minimum of 19.5% oxygen to breathe.
And you start at 0 nPa pressure, which is impossible. Even if it were possible, that means the planet wouldn't have enough gravity to hold on to any gasses, which makes creating oxygen rather moot- it would just go off into space. In my current game, I'm at 1,600 Pa, which is ridiculously low. Earth's standard pressure is about 100,000 Pa.
If we were to align these numbers more to reality, it would feel more believable, immersive, and even educational while still being entertaining. And yes, I know there's a system terraformation index, but the numbers can be changed to make that work properly. 

There's fun to be had here- but it needs more polish. Things were created in a simple manner but lazily implemented, which I think is my biggest issue with the game.

In my opinion, The Planet Crafter becomes repetitive fairly quickly. While the core idea of terraforming a barren world is exciting, the gameplay loop often settles into the same routine: gather resources, place machines, watch the numbers climb, and move on. After some time, this cycle starts to feel more like waiting than meaningful progression.

The building system also leaves a lot to be desired. Construction doesn’t feel smooth, and the game doesn’t offer much creative freedom when designing bases. Interiors often look awkward and disconnected. Decorative objects are hard to place nicely, frequently ending up misaligned, something that can be especially irritating for players who care about symmetry or aesthetics. Inside bases, the appearance of multiple structural pillars makes rooms look cluttered or visually unpleasant, breaking the sense of immersion instead of enhancing it.

Co-op gameplay has its own immersion-breaking issue: when a friend dies, there’s no option to revive them. They simply disappear in front of you, which removes emotional impact and eliminates interesting gameplay opportunities, like emergency rescues or support-based mechanics.

Inventory management also becomes frustrating. Items don’t stack, so your inventory fills up extremely quickly when gathering materials. Instead of creating a meaningful limitation, this system often just interrupts the flow of exploration. A more interesting alternative could be a weight-based system, forcing players to decide whether to gather more resources at the risk of running out of oxygen because they move slower or take longer to return.

On top of that, although exploration is pleasant at first, many areas follow a similar pattern: visit a wreck, loot what you can, bring it home, and repeat. Even as new biomes emerge during terraformation, the core experience doesn’t evolve as much as it could.

Despite all these shortcomings, the game genuinely has a lot of potential. Watching the world gradually transform can be incredibly satisfying, and the slow, atmospheric pace can be quite relaxing. The developers are active, and the community often praises their commitment to improving the game. However, for me, the repetitive nature of the progression and the limitations in building and inventory eventually wore me down. I ended up getting tired before reaching the phase where the planet becomes fully alive.

Overall, The Planet Crafter is enjoyable for players who like slow-paced survival and incremental progress. But if you’re looking for deep building mechanics, varied exploration, or more dynamic co-op systems, you might find it getting repetitive sooner than expected.

The game has potential, but it honestly doesn’t feel finished. It plays more like an early access title than a complete release. Multiplayer is disappointing, for example, when a friend dies you can’t revive or help them in any way, they simply disappear, which removes any sense of actual cooperation. Building also feels unpolished, I noticed that when you connect base rooms, the inside of your base just creates pillars all over the place because the game automatically adds these random support pillars that look terrible and completely break immersion.

The core idea of terraforming a planet is great, but the execution isn’t there yet. Animations feel stiff and unpolished, the UI is clunky and not intuitive, and the lack of tutorials makes the early game frustrating instead of engaging.

Inventory management is absolutely terrible. Storage feels limited, crafting menus are messy, poorly organized, and navigation feels like a chore. Items don’t stack, so you will end up spamming a bunch of boxes to store the immense amount of resources you’ll gather.

All of these problems together and probably some more I haven’t experienced because I couldn’t bear to play more of it, make the game feel far less polished than it should be. The foundation is good, and the concept has a lot of potential, but the current state doesn’t justify the price. I bought Planet Crafter on sale for 11,99€ and still didn’t feel like it was worth it, so I refunded it. Hope this review helps!

Planet Crafter is rated Overwhelmingly Positive on Steam. It's not that good. It's probably "fine" for a lot of people, not amazing for anyone.
Lots of people compare it to Subnautica. It's like an off-brand Subnautica imitation at best. It has visual and gameplay elements in common, but the atmosphere is way simpler.
The progression feels very forced. In Subnautica the progression was smooth as butter and very fun.
Progression was also very unbalanced. At times, we had a dozen upgrades to build, but had to spend hours gathering resources to build them. At other times we had to sit around for hours waiting for research to unlock. The pendulum swung so constantly and so far on this that it feels like the developers must be too busy/overwhelmed to actually tweak and balance this.
The fact that items don't stack is such an unbelievable tedium. We finally installed a mod that allowed for stacks of 10, and it felt better. Stacks of 3 or 5 might be "tight but manageable"... but stacks of 1 was just outright a waste of our time, walking back and forth over and over again. I'd estimate that we saved 50-75% of game time by being able to stack items. What took us 12 hours would've taken us 40 hours of running back and forth... not more fun, just more back-and-forth.
The exploration is disappointing, with only 10-20 things to find in the entire world. Subnautica felt like every few inches was something interesting to see.
The story was limited enough to feel like it was an afterthought. There are probably 5 pages of total text that we've uncovered so far, and the entire story could be summarized in about 5 sentences. Subnautica felt like it existed in a world, rather than having a story tacked on.
Graphics leave something to be desired. The tiling of textures was glaringly obvious, and some textures had noticeably lower fidelity than others.
Also, not much to do besides grind resources and wait for unlocks. Unimpressive base building (worse than Subnautica, which isn't the most impressive base-building system I've seen. Exploration exists and was a little fun, but ulimately limited in fruitfulness.

What this game does best is have the state of the world respond to your terraforming efforts. Not perfect, but quite good.
